column1: '''Nen Hithoel''' was a large lake upon the Great River [[Anduin]] amid the [[Emyn Muil]] to the east of [[Rohan]]. The lake was approximately 20 miles long from north to south, and 10 miles wide. The lake was formed by a narrow southern outlet and the small island of [[Tol Brandir]], which created a natural dam.<ref>{{RK
column2: Map}}</ref> Upon the lake's northern approach from Anduin the [[Men]] of [[Gondor]] carved the huge pillars of the [[Argonath]] in the reign of [[Rómendacil II]] to mark the northern boundary of their realm,<ref>{{App
column3: Gondor}}</ref> although by the time of the [[War of the Ring]] that boundary has long since receded. At the southern end of the lake stood three steep hills. [[Amon Hen]], the "Hill of Seeing", was upon the western shore and [[Amon Lhaw]], the "Hill of Hearing", was upon the east. The third hill formed the island of [[Tol Brandir]]. None ever set foot upon the island due to its sheer cliffs that rose directly from the river.<ref name="Break">{{FR

column1: Nen Hithoel is a [[Sindarin]] name, translated by Tolkien as "Mist-cool Water" in his unfinished index of the Lord of the Rings<ref name="Index">[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], "Unfinished Index", cited in: [[Wayne G. Hammond]], [[Christina Scull]], ''[[The Lord of the Rings: A Reader's Companion]]'', pp. 327-8</ref>. The elements are ''[[nen]]'' = "water", ''[[hîth]]'' = "mist" and ''oel'' "cool" (not otherwise attested). Note that the ([[Noldorin]]) word ''[[oel]]'' appeared in the earlier Etymologies of the 1930s with the meaning "pool, lake", but this word had changed to (Sindarin) ''[[ael]]'' by the time that the Lord of the Rings was written, and therefore could not have been an element of the name Nen Hithoel. Compare, for example, [[Aelin-uial]] with its earlier form Oelin-uial.<ref name="Etymologies">{{LR
